description:
You'll find absolute value absolutely straightforward--it is just the "distance from zero."  If you have a positive number, it is its own absolute value.  If you have a negative number, just make it positive to get the absolute value.  

As you'll see as you develop mathematically, this idea will eventually extend to more contexts and dimensions, so it's super important that you understand this core concept now.
title: Absolute value

children.title: Absolute value and number lines
children.description: One easy way to think of absolute value is the distance it is from zero. To do that, a number line comes in handy. Watch and learn.

children.title: Absolute value smallest to biggest
children.description: Not only will we identify several absolute values in this example, but we will order them from smallest to largest. Content provided by The NROC Project - ©Monterey Institute for Technology and Education
Find the absolute value of a given number.
children.title: Finding absolute values
Absolute value of integers
children.description: Let's mix a little algebra into our discussion of absolute value. What if we are looking for the |x|? If we know what x equals, we can do it. Follow along.

children.title: Comparing absolute values
children.description: When we compare numbers we use the concepts of greater than (>), less than (<), and equal to (=). The same is true of absolute values.
Compare the absolute values of two numbers, or compare the absolute value of one number to another number.
children.title: Comparing absolute values
Absolute value word problems
children.description: Here are a few word problems that ask us to apply our new absolute value knowledge. As with all word problems, read them a couple of times before jumping to an answer.

children.title: Constructing and interpreting absolute value
children.description: Watch as we apply our understanding of absolute value and adding/subtracting negative numbers to solve some word problems.

description: Whether you are trying to impress your dog's friends (who are obsessed with figuring out number divisibility) or quickly factor a number, it can be very useful to tell whether a number is divisible by another.  This tutorial walks through some of the more standard divisibility methods and describes why they work.
title: Divisibility tests

children.title: Divisibility tests for 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9, 10
children.description: Worked example of basic divisibility tests
Recognizing Divisibility
children.title: Recognizing divisibility

children.description: Why you can add the digits to see if something is divisible by 3
children.title: The why of the 3 divisibility rule

children.description: Why you can test divisibility by 9 by just adding the digits
children.title: The why of the 9 divisibility rule

description: In this tutorial, we'll begin to think about the numbers that "make up" the number.  This will be useful throughout our study of math.  Whether we are adding fractions, exploring mystical number patterns, or breaking computer codes, factoring numbers are key!  Eye of the tiger!
title: Divisibility and factors

children.title: Finding factors of a number
children.description: To find the factors of a number means to find all the whole numbers that the number in question is divisible by. Can you help us find the factors in this example?

children.title: Finding factors and multiples
children.description: Watch and listen as we explain a simple way of remembering the difference between factors and multiples.

children.title: Interactive module: finding factors
children.description: Here's a video of Sal working on a exercise which helps you visualize the process of finding a number's factors.
Practice finding factor pairs for whole numbers.
children.title: Factor pairs

children.description: Demonstrate understanding of factors and multiples.
children.title: Identifying factors and multiples

description: Prime numbers have been studied by mathematicians and mystics for ages (seriously).  They are both basic and mysterious.  The more you explore them, the more you will realize that the universe is a fascinating place.  This tutorial will introduce you to the magical world of prime numbers.
title: Prime numbers

children.title: Prime numbers
children.description: What does it mean to be a prime number? Let's progress though some whole numbers and ask ourselves if they meet the criteria. What is the criteria you ask? Watch.

children.title: Recognizing prime and composite numbers
children.description: Can you recognize the prime numbers in this group of numbers? Which are prime, composite, or neither?

description: You know what prime numbers are and how to identify them.  In this tutorial, we'll see that *all* positive whole numbers can be broken down into products of prime numbers (In some way, prime numbers are the "atoms" of the number world that can be multiplied to create any other number).  Besides being a fascinating idea, it is also extremely useful.  Prime factorization can be used to decrypt encrypted information!
title: Prime factorization

children.description: Prime Factorization
children.title: Prime factorization

children.description: Ben Eater and Sal walk through the "Fundamental theorem of arithmetic" module: http://www.khanacademy.org/math/arithmetic/factors-multiples/e/the_fundamental_theorem_of_arithmetic
children.title: The fundamental theorem of arithmetic

children.description: Common Divisibility Examples
children.title: Common divisibility examples

description: Life is good, but it can always get better.  Just imagine being able to find the smallest number that is a multiple of two other numbers!  Other than making your life more fulfilling, it will allow you to do incredible things like adding fractions.
title: Least common multiple

children.title: Least common multiple exercise
children.description: We're practicing finding the least common multiple in these example exercises. We'll teach you the prime factorization approach which is a pretty nifty way to find the lcm (least common multiple).

children.title: Least common multiple exercise 2
children.description: Here's a lcm (least common multiple) example exercise that's a little but harder, but totally doable. Again, we'll use the prime factorization approach.

children.title: Least common multiple exercise: 3 numbers
children.description: This least common multiple example gives us 3 numbers from which to find the lcm. This is a challenge, but fun. Do it with us!

description: You know how to find factors of a number.  But what about factors that are common to two numbers?  Even better, imagine the largest factors that are common to two numbers.   I know.  Too exciting!
title: Greatest common divisor

children.title: Greatest common factor exercise
children.description: Find the biggest number that will divide into the given 2 numbers. This is called the GCF or greatest common factor.No worries, we'll show you how to do it.

children.title: Greatest common factor explained
children.description: Here's a nice explanation of least common factor (or least common divisor) along with a few practice example exercises. Let's roll.

children.title: LCM and GCF word problems
children.description: Here we have a couple of word problems--one searching for the least common multiple and the other for the greatest common factor. Just read them with us slowly and follow along. You'll get it.

description: You've been using decimals all of your life.  When you pay $0.75 at a vending machine, 0.75 is a decimal.  When you see the ratings of gymnastics judges at the Olympics ("9.5, 9.4, 7.5 (booooo)"), those are decimals.  This tutorial will help you understand this powerful tool all the better.  Before you know it, you'll be representing numbers that are in-between whole numbers all the time!
title: Conceptualizing decimals and place notation

children.description: Decimal Place Value
children.title: Decimal place value
Decimals: writing it out in words
children.description: By writing out a decimal in words, you're forced to really show your understanding of it. Give it a try!

children.title: Decimals: writing it out in words 2
children.description: Here's another example involving writing out a decimal in words. Great practice.

children.title: Decimals: expanding out place value
children.description: Let's expand a decimal out and really try to understand what it represents.

children.title: Decimals: writing it out as a number
children.description: Take your time and remember your order of operations as you translate this into a decimal number.

children.title: Decimals: comparing place values
children.description: We're having a blast with decimals! Check this one: we're comparing place values. This will blow your mind.

children.title: Decimals: choosing a number to represent place value
children.description: Let's decide the number of each place value to make the given decimal. We can do it together!

children.title: Money and decimal place value intuition

description: Let's explore how we can regroup and redistribute value among the various place values in a decimal number.
title: Regrouping decimals

children.title: Regrouping with decimals
children.description: We're doing more regrouping but this time using decimals. Just remember those place values!

children.title: Regrouping with decimals example 1
children.description: Similar to a problem we did earlier but with whole numbers, this time we're having to regroup with decimals and find the right answer. Take your time.

children.title: Regrouping decimals example 2
children.description: Great decimal regrouping exercise. Do this one with us and see how well you've mastered the regrouping decimal topic!

description: Let's think about where decimals are on a number line.  It will help us understand what decimals represent in general!
title: Decimals on a number line

children.title: Decimals on a number line
children.description: Let's compare decimals on a number line, shall we?

children.title: Decimals and fractions on a number line
children.description: We're mixing it up by placing both fractions and decimals on the same number line. Great practice because you need to move effortlessly between the two.

children.title: Placing positive and negative decimals on a number line
children.description: These example exercises require us to interpret a number line in order to locate where our positive and negative decimals should be placed.

description: Let's test our understanding of decimals by comparing them to one another!
title: Comparing decimals

children.title: Comparing decimals example 1
children.description: When comparing decimals it's easy to get confused by the number of digits to the right of decimal. Is it a tenth, hundredth, or thousandth? This video will help you a lot!

children.title: Comparing decimals example 2
children.description: We're using the less than (<) and greater than (>) symbols to compare decimals now. Cool!

children.title: Comparing decimals: difference in largest place value
children.description: Confused trying to determine which decimal is larger? Let's compare two decimals in this example. Remember that you're looking for the difference is the largest place value to find the larger decimal.

children.title: Comparing decimals: place value difference
children.description: It's not uncommon to be asked to compare two decimals and judge which one is larger. How do you do that? This video will gave you the confidence to answer that question.

children.title: Comparing decimals: ordering from least to greatest
children.description: This is a fun example where we reorder decimals from smallest to largest. You're looking for the place value that is the most signifiant, and then working backwards.

children.title: Comparing decimals: ordering from smallest to biggest
children.description: Let's move the decimals around and reorder them from least to greatest. Hint: look at one place value and then compare it to the decimals before moving on to the next place value.

description: You get the general idea of decimal is and what the digits in different places represent (place value).  Now you're ready to do something with the decimals.  Adding and subtracting is a good place to start.  This will allow you to add your family's expenses to figure out if your little brother is laundering money (perhaps literally).  Have fun!
title: Adding and subtracting decimals

children.title: Adding decimals: example 1
children.description: Line those decimals up first. Careful!

children.title: Adding decimals: example 2
children.description: Let's practice another adding decimal problem. We'll do it together.

children.title: Adding decimals: example 3
children.description: We're adding 3 decimal numbers together in this example. Give it a try!

children.title: Subtracting decimals: example 1
children.description: Subtracting decimals...up to the hundredths placement. Line up those decimals before you start.

children.title: Subtracting decimals example 1
children.description: Just like when add, be sure you align decimals before subtracting.

children.title: Adding decimals word problem
children.description: Here's a simple word problem asking us to put our adding decimals skill to work. We sound like a broken record, but be sure and ALIGN DECIMALS.

children.title: Adding and subtracting decimals word problem
children.description: Let's get fancy and practice adding and subtracting decimals in the same word problem.

children.title: Adding and subtracting decimals word problems
Subtracting decimals (old)
children.description: Subtracting decimal numbers

description: The real world is seldom about whole numbers.  If you precisely measure anything, you're likely to get a decimal.  If you don't know how to multiply these decimals, then you won't be able to do all the powerful things that multiplication can do in the real world (figure out your commission as a robot possum salesperson, determining how much shag carpet you need for your secret lair, etc.).
title: Multiplying decimals

children.title: Introduction to multiplying decimals
children.description: Multiplying decimals can be confusing because there's always the question as to where the decimals goes in the answer. We're about to show you so you'll never have to question it again!

children.title: Multiplying decimals word problem
children.description: We're multiplying decimals again, but this time answering a common question: what's the cost of filling up the car tank?

children.title: Multiplying decimals: place value and reordering
children.description: We want you to develop an intuition about how to work with decimals. Understanding how you can rewrite decimals by considering the place value will help you multiply!

children.title: Multiplying decimals example
children.description: Multiplying decimals? Try multiplying without the decimals first, them add them back in. We'll show you.

children.title: Multiplying challenging decimals
children.description: Sometimes multiplying really small decimals (with all those zeros!) can be a little intimidating. Watch as we show you a handy trick to simplify these problems and solve them.

description: You can add, subtract and multiply decimals.  You know you'd feel a bit empty if you couldn't divide them as well. But something more powerful is going to happen.  If you are like us, you never quite liked those pesky remainders when dividing whole numbers.  Well, those pesky remainders better watch out because they are going to be divided too!!!! Ah ha ha ha ha!!!!!
title: Dividing decimals

children.title: Dividing completely to get decimal answer
children.description: Sometimes, in order divide numbers completely you have to add a decimal and bring down places. Let's do it together, shall we?

children.title: Dividing completely to get decimal answer example 2
children.description: Sometimes the number that you're dividing by is smaller than the number that is being divided and won't go into it even once! What do you do? Watch.

children.title: Dividing a decimal by a whole number
children.description: You're doing great. Now we want to mix it up a little: divide a decimal by a whole number. Follow along.

children.title: Dividing a whole number by a decimal
children.description: When dividing a whole number by a decimal, you're going to need to change that decimal into a whole number. How? We'll show you.

children.title: Dividing by a multi-digit decimal
children.description: Let's do one more decimal division problem together but change it up. This is one with a decimal divisor and will require you to shift the decimal first.

children.title: Dividing decimals with hundredths example 3
children.description: The old saying is "practice makes perfect." Let's keep practicing dividing decimals and making our divisor a whole number.

description: Both fractions and decimals are desperate to capture that little part of our heart that desires to express non-whole numbers.  But must we commit?  Can't we have business in the front and party in the back (younger people should look up the word "mullet" to see a hair-style worth considering for your next trip to the barber)?  Can't it look like a pump, but feel like a sneaker?  Well, if 18-wheelers can turn into self-righteous robots, then why can't decimals and fractions turn into each other?
title: Converting between fractions and decimals

children.title: Fraction to decimal with rounding
children.description: Sometimes when you convert a fraction to a decimal you have to do some long division and rounding.

children.title: Fraction to decimal example
children.description: This is a great example of converting a fraction to a decimal. Use a scratch pad so you can follow along.
How to express a fraction as a decimal
children.title: Converting fractions to decimals
Fraction to decimal
children.description: Converting fractions to decimals sometimes requires us to brush up on our long division skills. We'll walk you through it.
Convert a fraction to decimal rounded to the nearest thousandth.
children.title: Converting fractions to decimals
Decimal to simplified fraction
children.description: Here's an example of how we convert a decimal to a simplified fraction. Over time this will become second nature to you.

children.title: Converting decimals to fractions example 1
children.description: We're practicing how to convert a lonely decimal into a happy fraction.

children.title: Converting decimals to fractions example 2
children.description: Being a decimal is hard. Everyone picks on you. Not like those lucky fractions. Let's convert the decimal together.

children.title: Converting decimals to fractions example 3
children.description: Converting this decimal results in a fraction that needs to be simplified. Can you help us?
Convert a decimal to an equivalent fraction. Convert a decimal to an equivalent mixed number.
children.title: Converting decimals to fractions 2
The meaning of percent
children.description: Let's start by thinking about what percent really means. Once you understand this, other pieces will begin to fall into place.

children.title: The meaning of percent over 100
children.description: How does our meaning of percent (per "hundred") translate when we need to understand a percent OVER a hundred?

children.title: Converting percent to decimal and fraction
children.description: You'll find that be able to move easily between percentages, decimals, and fractions is HUGELY helpful. So let's practice!

children.title: Converting decimals to percents
children.description: Need to convert a decimal to a percent? Ok, we'll just use our fraction friends to get us there. Watch and be amazed.

children.title: Converting decimals to percents example 2
children.description: Understanding how to convert a decimal to a percent comes in really handy sometimes. Let's practice using this problem.

children.title: Converting percents to decimals
children.description: Remember that "per cent" means "per hundred." Knowing that, converting a percent to a decimal is done by dividing by a 100. We'll demonstrate.

children.title: Converting percents to decimals example 2
children.description: Practice another conversion problem, this time from percent to decimal. Arriving at the answer is as simple as dividing by 100!

children.title: Finding a percentage
children.description: Once again, fractions are our friends as we use them to find a percentage. You'll also see a couple of different ways to arrive at the answer.

children.title: Percent word problem
children.description: It's nice to practice conversion problems, but how about applying our new knowledge of percentages to a real life problem like recycling? Hint: don't forget your long division!
Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100; solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.
children.title: Finding percents

children.description: Identifying Percent Amount and Base
children.title: Identifying percent amount and base
Representing a number as a decimal, percent, and fraction 2
children.description: Representing a number as a decimal, percent, and fraction 2

children.title: Ordering numeric expressions
children.description: Ordering numbers expressed as decimals, fractions, and percentages

children.title: Percentage of a whole number
children.description: We hope you're beginning to see that there's more than one way to skin a cat. In other words, there are several different ways to solve problems involving percentages, decimals, and fractions. Watch as find the percentage of a whole number.

children.title: Basic example of rewriting a fraction as a decimal
children.description: Let's watch as Sal gives us a basic example of how to rewrite a fraction as a decimal. This will make a lot of sense!

children.title: Rewriting fraction as a decimal to the hundredths place
children.description: As our earlier example, the goal is to simply the fraction and then convert it--this time in terms of hundredths.

description: Whether you're calculating a tip at your favorite restaurant or figuring out how many decades you'll be paying your student debt because of the interest, percents will show up again and again and again in your life.  This tutorial will expose you to some of these problems before they show up in your actual life so you can handle them with ease (kind of like a vaccine for the brain).  Enjoy.
title: Percent word problems

children.title: Growing by a percentage
children.description: In this example we grow a whole number by a percentage of itself. Growing by percentage is a common skill often used when figuring how much is owed or earned with interest.

children.title: Solving percent problems
children.description: We'll use algebra to solve this percent problem.

children.title: Percent word problem example 4
children.description: This word problem is expressed simply which can be confusing to some. Take your time and focus on the what is being asked for.

children.title: Percent word problem example 5
children.description: In this example, you working with us to find the number that is expressed as a given percentage.We'll create a simple algebraic equation to solve!

children.title: Discount, tax, and tip word problems

description:
Laziness is usually considered a bad thing.  But sometimes, it is useful to be lazy in a smart way.  Why do a big, hairy calculation if you just need a rough estimate? Why keep track of 2.345609 when you only need 2.35? 

This tutorial will get you comfortable with sometimes being a little rough with numbers.  By being able to round and estimate them, it'll only add one more tool to your toolkit.
title: Estimating and rounding with decimals

children.title: Rounding decimals: to the nearest tenth
children.description: Rounding. Oh my....there will be so many times when rounding numbers (including decimals) will be a required skill. Let's get this down, shall we?

description:
There is a strong temptation in life to appear precise, even when you are aren't accurate.   If you  precisely measure one dimension of a carpet to be 3.256 meters and eyeball the other dimensional to be "roughly 2 meters", can you really claim that the area is  6.512 square meters (3.256 x 2)?  Isn't that a little misleading?  

This tutorial gets us thinking about this conundrum and gives us the best practices that scientists and engineers use to not mislead each other.
title: Significant figures

children.description: Introduction to significant figures
children.title: Significant figures

children.description: Understanding the "rules of thumb" for significant figures
children.title: More on significant figures

children.description: Addition and Subtraction with Significant Figures
children.title: Addition and subtraction with significant figures

children.description: Multiplying and dividing with significant figures
children.title: Multiplying and dividing with significant figures

children.description: Determine how many significant figures a given number has.
children.title: Significant figures

description: In our decimal number system, as we move places to the left, the place values increase by a factor of 10 (likewise, they decrease by a factor of 10 as we move rightward).  This idea gets direct application when we multiply or divide a decimal number by 10 because it has the effect of shifting every place value one to the right or left (sometime seen as moving the decimal point).
title: Moving the decimal to multiply and divide by 10

children.title: Multiplying a decimal by a power of 10
children.description: You will notice in this word problem that moving the decimal to the right the same number of times as the number of zeros you multiplying by gets you the answer you desire. Check this out!

children.title: Dividing a decimal by a power of 10
children.description: When we were multiplying, we moved the decimal to the right for each power of ten. Guess what? When dividing, we move the decimal to the left for each power of ten.

children.title: Dividing a decimal by a power of 10: shortcut
children.description: Holy cow! A shortcut? Yep. For each ten you multiply or divide by, just shift that decimal to the right or left. Watch this and be amazed.
Convert fractions to decimal form.
children.title: Fractions as division by 10 or 100

description: If you think you know how to convert between decimals, fractions and percentages and are familiar with negative numbers, this tutorial is a good place to test all of those skills at the same time.
title: Adding and subtracting decimals percentages and fractions

children.title: Adding, subtracting numbers in different formats
children.description: In this example, we solve an addition problem with numbers in different formats: a percentage, decimal, and mixed number. First, we'll get them all in the same format...which makes it a while easier to solve!

children.title: Adding, subtracting fractions, decimals, percentages
children.description: What happens when we are asked to add or subtract fractions, decimals, and percentages? You'll see in this example that we first get them in the same format, and then add fractions.

children.title: Adding, subtracting fractions
children.description: Our focus here is on learning to multiply fractions. First we have to get the common denominator, then add positive and negative numbers.

children.title: Adding and subtracting negative fractions, decimals, and percents

description:
If you don't understand fractions, you won't be even 1/3 educated.  Glasses will seem half empty rather than half full.  You'll be lucky to not be duped into some type of shady real-estate scheme or putting far too many eggs in your cake batter.

Good thing this tutorial is here.  You'll see that fractions allow us to view the world in entirely new ways.  You'll see that everything doesn't have to be a whole.  You'll be able to slice and dice and then put it all back together (and if you order now, we'll throw in a spatula warmer for no extra charge).
title: Understanding fractions

children.description: Identifying Fraction Parts
children.title: Identifying fraction parts

children.description: Numerator and Denominator of a Fraction
children.title: Numerator and denominator of a fraction
Plotting basic fractions on the number line

description: Do you want 2/3 or 4/6 of this pizza?  Doesn't matter because they are both the same fraction.  This tutorial will help us explore this idea by really visualizing what equivalent fractions represent.
title: Visualizing equivalent fractions

children.title: Visualizing equivalent fractions
children.description: To understand equivalent fractions it helps to "see" the fractions using something like a grid with shaded and unshaded sections representing the fraction. This will help a ton!

children.title: Equivalent fraction word problem example
children.description: Your teachers will tell you that being able to apply (or put to use) concepts helps you to learn them better. Here's a word problem in which you have to apply your knowledge of equivalent fractions.

children.title: Equivalent fraction word problem example 2
children.description: How do you find an equivalent fraction? If you know the denominator of both fractions, and the numerator of one of them...you can figure out the rest We'll show you in this word problem.

children.title: Equivalent fraction word problem example 3
children.description: We're comparing fractions using the info given in this word problem. Can you find the equivalent one?

description:
There are literally infinite ways to represent any fraction (or number for that matter).  Don't believe us?  Let's take 1/3.  2/6, 3/9, 4/12 ... 10001/30003 are all equivalent fractions (and we could keep going)!  

If you know the basics of what a fraction is, this is a great tutorial for recognizing when fractions are equivalent and then simplifying them as much as possible!
title: Equivalent fractions and simplified form

children.description: Fractions in lowest terms
children.title: Fractions in lowest terms

children.description: Introduces the concept of equivalent fractions
children.title: Equivalent fractions
Equivalent fraction word problem example 4
children.description: How may times have you been told, "Save your money!" We thought so. What if you wanted to save a fractional amount of your allowance? How would you go about figuring out how much to save?
Finding Common Denominators
children.title: Finding common denominators

description: In this tutorial, we'll practice understanding what quantities fractions actually represent and comparing those to each other.
title: Comparing fractions

children.title: Comparing fractions with greater than and less than symbols
Comparing fractions with like numerators and denominators
Comparing fractions with the same numerator or denominator

children.description: Comparing Fractions
children.title: Comparing fractions
Comparing fractions with different denominators
children.description: Comparing fractions? Try simplifying them first then finding a common denominator. The result are two fractions you can really compare.

children.title: Comparing fractions with different numerators and denominators
Comparing and ordering fractions
children.description: Finding common denominators of multiple fractions to order them

description: In this tutorial, we'll see that a fraction can be broken up (or decomposed) into a bunch of other fractions.  You might see the world in a completely different way after this.
title: Decomposing fractions

children.title: Decomposing a fraction visually
children.description: It helps to visually understand what decomposing a fraction looks like. We're pretty sure you're going to like this.

children.title: Decomposing a mixed number
children.description: Decomposing mixed numbers is a pretty straightforward process. It's as simple as adding fractions with like denominators. Watch us do it!

children.title: Adding up fractions
children.description: We need the sum of all the fractions to equal the given fraction. Can you help us choose which ones to use?

description: We've already had some good practice adding fractions with like denominators.  We'll now add fractions with unlike denominators. This is a very big deal.  After this tutorial, you'll be able to add, pretty much, any two (or three or four or... ) fractions!
title: Adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators

children.title: Adding fractions with unlike denominators: units of 10
children.description: A great way to learn how to add fractions with unlike demoninators is to do so with denominators in units of 10 and 100. Like this...

children.title: Adding fractions with 10 and 100 as denominators

children.description: How to add and subtract fractions.
children.title: Adding and subtracting fractions
Adding fractions: different denominators
children.description: To solve this problem, we need to find the least common multiple to get at the common denominator. Can you help? We bet you can!

children.title: Adding fractions: common denominator
children.description: To add these fractions we need to find a common denominator. The answer can be expressed as a mixed number. Let's try together.

children.title: Subtracting fractions: different denominators
children.description: If you conquered adding fractions with different denominators, then subtracting fractions will be a snap. Don't worry...we'll take it slow and explain every step.

children.title: Adding fractions with different signs
children.description: As we learn about fractions, this is a good time to add the complexity of negative numbers as fractions. Let's practice adding fractions with different signs!

children.title: Adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators

description:
You've already got 2 cups of sugar in the cupboard.  Your grandmother's recipe for disgustingly-sweet-fudge-cake calls for 3 and 1/3 cups of sugar.  How much sugar do you need to borrow from you robot neighbor?

Adding and subtracting fractions is key.  It might be a good idea to look at the equivalent fractions tutorial before tackling this one.
title: Adding and subtracting fractions

children.title: Adding fractions with like denominators
children.description: With like denominators, you're basically just adding numerators. That's not too bad, right? Can the resulting fraction be simplified?

children.title: Subtracting  fractions with like denominators
children.description: Just like when we added...subtracting fractions is pretty straightforward when the two fractions have like denominators.

children.title: Word problem: What fraction of spider eyes are looking at me?
children.description: You mean a spider has MORE than 2 eyes? Yikes!

children.title: Word problem: What fraction of an hour should the piano still be practiced?
children.description: Better get practicing, Pedro! You have exactly (a fraction) more of an hour to practice the piano.

children.title: Word problem: How long is this lizard?
children.description: Add the fractions to find out how long this lizard is.

children.title: Adding and subtracting fractions with like denominators word problems

description: You know what a fraction is and are now eager to apply this knowledge to real-world situations (especially ones where the denominators aren't equal)?  Well, you're about to see that adding and subtracting fractions is far more powerful (and fun) then you've ever dreamed possible!
title: Adding and subtracting with unlike denominator word problems

children.title: Adding fractions with unlike denominators: word problem
children.description: We can do math problem all day long, but to really understand math--you have to apply it. Let's apply adding fractions to this word problem.

children.title: Subtracting fractions with unlike denominators: word problem
children.description: To find the answer to this word problem, we'll have to convert the mixed numbers into improper fractions first.

children.title: Adding and subtracting fractions with unlike denominators word problems

description:
What is 2/3 of 2/3? If 4/7 of the class are boys, how many boys are there?

Multiplying fractions is not only super-useful, but super-fun as well.
title: Multiplying fractions

children.title: Multiplying fractions and whole numbers
children.description: Don't let multiplying whole numbers and factions get you down. We got this. This explanation will help you become a pro.

children.title: Multiplying two fractions: an explanation
children.description: This video will help you think about what it means to multiply two fractions. By drawing the problem and "seeing" the answer, you'll better understand how we arrived at it.

children.title: Multiplying two fractions: example
children.description: Let's practice multiplying two fractions together. We'll learn to simplify the answer, too.
Multiplying positive fractions with simplification
children.title: Multiplying positive fractions
Multiplying negative and positive fractions
children.description: Let's take a stab on practicing one of the most commonly used math skills: multiplying and dividing fractions. We'll use a few examples with negative numbers.

children.title: Multiplication as scaling
children.description: When multiplying fractions, it's sometimes helpful to view the operation as a kind of scaling--that multiplying the fraction times another creates a fractional proportion, or scale. Watch. You'll understand.

description:
Multiplying fractions is useful. Period. That's all we really have to say.  Believe us don't believe us.  You'll learn eventually.  

This tutorial will have you multiplying in real-world scenarios (which is almost as fun as completely artificial, fake scenarios).
title: Multiplying fractions word problems

children.title: Multiplying fractions word problem: movie marathon
children.description: We want to do a movie marathon! Let's figure out how long our marathon will last if each movie length is represented as a mixed number.

children.title: Multiplying fractions word problem: milk love
children.description: Who doesn't love milk? Our family sure does. Let's figure out how much milk is consumed each month if each person consumes a fractional amount of milk.

children.title: Multiplying fractions word problem: pigging out on pumpkin pie
children.description: Oops! Someone tried to solve this problem and made a mistake. See if you can spot the error.

children.title: Multiplying fractions and whole numbers word problems
Multiplying fractions word problem: banana oat muffin recipe
children.description: We hope you learn to cook. Everyone should! At some point you'll need to make 1/2 a recipe which means using 1/2 of every ingredient in the recipe. Here's an example.

children.title: Multiplying fractions word problem: laundry emergency
children.description: Someone is about to run out of laundry detergent which means sticky clothes! Help her estimate how much she has left.

children.title: Multiplying fractions word problem: bike to a friend
children.description: You know how long it takes to bike to your friend's house, and you know how fast your can ride. So how far away does your friend live? The answer is one fraction multiplication problem away!

children.title: Multiplying fractions by fractions word problems

description: We can often have fractions whose numerators are not less than the denominators (like 23/4  or 3/2 or even 6/6).  These top-heavy friends are called improper fractions.  Since they represent a whole or more (in absolute terms), they can also be expressed as a combination of a whole number and a "proper fraction" (one where the numerator is less than the denominator) which is called a "mixed number."  They are both awesome ways of representing a number and getting acquainted with both (as this tutorial does) is super useful in life!
title: Mixed numbers and improper fractions

children.description: Worked examples comparing improper fractions and mixed numbers
children.title: Comparing improper fractions and mixed numbers

children.description: Converting mixed numbers to improper fractions and improper fractions to mixed numbers
children.title: Mixed numbers and improper fractions

children.description: Proper and Improper Fractions
children.title: Proper and improper fractions

children.description: Converting Mixed Numbers to Improper Fractions
children.title: Converting mixed numbers to improper fractions
Mixed numbers: changing to improper fractions
children.description: What if we wanted to change a mixed number into an improper fraction? How would we go about doing that? Let's see!

children.title: Mixed numbers: changing from an improper fraction
children.description: Let's help our top-heavy improper fraction friend switch over into a mixed number!

children.title: Converting mixed numbers and improper fractions
Mixed number or improper fraction on a number line
children.description: Fraction or mixed number...either way you should end up on the same spot on the number line. Give it a try with us.

children.title: Fractions cut and copy 2 exercise example
Decimals and fractions on a number line
children.description: We're mixing it up by placing both fractions and decimals on the same number line. Great practice because you need to move effortlessly between the two.

children.title: Positive and negative fractions on the number line

description: You know the basics of what mixed numbers are.  You're now ready to add and subtract them.  This tutorial gives you plenty of examples and practice in this core skill!
title: Mixed number addition and subtraction

children.description: Adding Mixed Numbers
children.title: Adding mixed numbers

children.description: Adding Mixed Numbers with Unlike Denominators
children.title: Adding mixed numbers with unlike denominators

children.description: Adding Mixed Numbers Word Problem
children.title: Adding mixed numbers word problem

children.description: Subtracting Mixed Numbers
children.title: Subtracting mixed numbers

children.description: Subtracting Mixed Numbers 2
children.title: Subtracting mixed numbers 2

children.description: Subtracting Mixed Numbers Word Problem
children.title: Subtracting mixed numbers word problem
Adding mixed numbers with like denominators
children.description: Think of a mixed numbers as a number AND a fraction. You can add numbers....you can add fractions with like denominators. Therefore, you can add mixed numbers! Watch.

children.title: Subtracting mixed numbers with like denominators
children.description: Think of a mixed numbers as a number AND a fraction. You can subtract numbers....you can subtract fractions with like denominators. Therefore, you can subtract mixed numbers! Watch.

children.title: Adding and subtracting mixed numbers with like denominators
Adding mixed numbers
children.description: You know mixed numbers, right? A number that is both a whole number and a proper fraction? Let's add a few together. If this is new to you, no worries. We'll explain everything.

children.title: Subtracting mixed numbers
children.description: Although this sounds like strictly a subtraction problem, it's also partially addition in that we have mixed numbers. By definition, a mixed number includes a whole number added to a proper fraction. We'll clarify it and with a little practice, you'll impress your friends.

children.title: Adding and subtracting mixed numbers with unlike denominators

description:
My recipe calls for a cup and a half of blueberries and serves 10 people.  But I have 23 people coming over.  How many cups of blueberries do I need?

You know that mixed numbers and improper fractions are two sides of the same coin (and you can convert between the two).  In this tutorial we'll learn to multiply and divide mixed numbers (mainly by converting them into improper fractions first).
title: Mixed number multiplication and division

children.title: Multiplying fractions and whole numbers: mixed number answer
children.description: Sometimes the product of multiplying fractions and whole numbers is a mixed number. Mixed up? You won't be for long!

children.title: Multiplying mixed numbers
children.description: We've learned to multiplying two fractions and a fraction and a whole number. Let's move on to multiplying mixed numbers!
Reciprocal of a Mixed Number
children.title: Reciprocal of a mixed number

children.description: Dividing Mixed Numbers
children.title: Dividing mixed numbers

children.description: Dividing Mixed Numbers and Fractions
children.title: Dividing mixed numbers and fractions

description: If you already know a bit about both decimals and fractions, this tutorial will help build a bridge between the two.  Through a bunch of examples and practice, you'll be able operate in both worlds.  Have fun!
title: Decimals and fractions

children.title: Decimal to simplified fraction
children.description: Here's an example of how we convert a decimal to a simplified fraction. Over time this will become second nature to you.

children.title: Fraction to decimal
children.description: Converting fractions to decimals sometimes requires us to brush up on our long division skills. We'll walk you through it.

children.title: Fraction to decimal with rounding
children.description: Sometimes when you convert a fraction to a decimal you have to do some long division and rounding.

children.title: Fraction to decimal example
children.description: This is a great example of converting a fraction to a decimal. Use a scratch pad so you can follow along.
Convert a fraction to decimal rounded to the nearest thousandth.
children.title: Converting fractions to decimals

children.description: How to express a fraction as a decimal
children.title: Converting fractions to decimals
Converting percent to decimal and fraction
children.description: You'll find that be able to move easily between percentages, decimals, and fractions is HUGELY helpful. So let's practice!

children.title: Converting decimals to fractions example 1
children.description: We're practicing how to convert a lonely decimal into a happy fraction.

children.title: Converting decimals to fractions example 2
children.description: Being a decimal is hard. Everyone picks on you. Not like those lucky fractions. Let's convert the decimal together.

children.title: Converting decimals to fractions example 3
children.description: Converting this decimal results in a fraction that needs to be simplified. Can you help us?
Convert a decimal to an equivalent fraction. Convert a decimal to an equivalent mixed number.
children.title: Converting decimals to fractions 2
Ordering numeric expressions
children.description: Ordering numbers expressed as decimals, fractions, and percentages

children.title: Converting a fraction to a repeating decimal

description: This is one exciting tutorial.  In it, we will understand that fractions can represent division (and the other way around).  Then we will create fractions by dividing whole numbers and then start dividing the fractions themselves.  We'll see that dividing by something is the exact same thing as multiplying by that thing's reciprocal!
title: Dividing fractions

children.title: Creating a fraction through division of whole numbers
children.description: Remember that a whole number is actually a fraction, too? In this video we'll look at dividing whole numbers as fractions and how that leads to fractional answers!

children.title: Mixed numbers on a number line
children.description: Understanding how an improper fraction is transformed into a mixed number using a number line.

children.title: Dividing whole numbers and fractions: potpourri
children.description: You know how to divide whole numbers...you probably know how to divide fractions, but what about dividing whole numbers AND fractions? This word problem will give us a real life application

children.title: Dividing whole numbers and fractions: studying
children.description: As you work this division word problem using whole numbers and fractions, don't forget to invert and multiply!

children.title: Dividing whole numbers and fractions: t-shirts
children.description: Dividing a whole number by a fraction? Turn the tables and multiply by the reciprocal of the fraction. Boom!
Dividing positive fractions with simplification
children.title: Dividing fractions by whole numbers
Division with fractions and whole numbers word problems

description: In this tutorial, we'll become fraction dividing experts!  In particular, we'll understand what it means to divide a fraction by another fraction.  Too much fun!!!
title: Dividing fractions by fractions

children.title: Understanding division of fractions
children.description: Using a number line, we'll explain the rule of "invert and multiply" when dividing two fractions.

children.title: Dividing fractions example
children.description: This is a straightforward example of dividing two fractions. We'll make super clear!

children.title: Dividing fractions example 2
children.description: Let's take another stab at dividing two fractions. This time the answer should be a mixed number.

children.title: Dividing fractions by fractions and whole numbers applications
Dividing negative fractions
children.description: Here we'll practice dividing fractions, including negatives. Remember that when we divide fractions we use the reciprocal and multiply.

description: The world of numbers can be split up into multiple "sets", many of which overlap with each other (integers, rational numbers, irrational numbers, etc.).  This tutorial works through examples that expose you to the terminology of the various sets and how you can differentiate them.
title: Number sets

children.description: Number Sets
children.title: Number sets

children.description: Number Sets 1
children.title: Number sets 1

children.description: Number Sets 2
children.title: Number sets 2

children.description: Number Sets 3
children.title: Number sets 3

description:
Would you rather go to a college with a high teacher-to-student ratio or a low one?  What about the ratio of girls-to-boys?  What is the ratio of eggs to butter in your favorite dessert?

Ratios show up EVERYWHERE in life.  This tutorial introduces you to what they (and proportions) are and how to make good use of them!
title: Ratios and proportions

children.title: Introduction to ratios
children.description: What a ratio is.  Simple ratio problems.
Ratios as Fractions in Simplest Form
children.title: Ratios as fractions in simplest form

children.description: Simplifying Rates and Ratios
children.title: Simplifying rates and ratios
Ratio word problem: boys to girls
children.description: In this example, we are given a ratio and then asked to apply that ratio to solve a problem. No problem!

children.title: Ratio word problem: centimeters to kilometers
children.description: Let's solve this word problem using what we know about ratios so far.
Understanding Proportions
children.title: Proportion validity example
Solving ratio problems with tables example 1
children.description: We're displaying ratios in a table format here, and then asking: given a ratio, solve for equivalent ratios. Here are a few examples to practice on.

children.title: Solving ratio problems with tables example 2
children.description: Let's compare 2 tables of ratios and interpret them to solve the word problem. This is a fun!

children.title: Solving ratio problems with graph
children.description: In this example we'll plot points on the x and y axis to reflect the given ratios.

description:
How fast can a robot possum fly?  What is the rate at which a hungry you can consume avocados?  

This tutorial helps you make sense of these fundamental questions in life.
title: Rates

children.title: Finding average speed or rate
children.description: Using the formula for finding distance we can determine Usian Bolt's average speed, or rate, when he broke the world record in 2009 in the 100m. Watch.

children.title: Solving unit rates problem
children.description: Finding a unit rate is a skill often required in real life. How fast is that plane flying? How many lawns can you mow in an afternoon? You see, with our knowledge of ratios and fractions, we can now solve unit rates problems like this.

children.title: Solving unit price problem
children.description: Using our knowledge of fractions, we can solve this unit price problem. Remember to keep your units of measure consistent.

children.title: Multiple rates word problem
children.description: Sometimes you'll need to solve for multiple parts of the equation before getting at the answer. Here we solve for average speed, but first we have to determine total distance and total time.

description:
Wait, I'm in Europe and my car only tells my distance traveled in kilometers!  But I'm used to a units of distance devised by the Romans to measure the average length of 1000 paces of a soldier (the "mile")!  How do I operate?  

This tutorial is about the fundamental skill of unit conversion.  Sal's cousin Nadia being a bit confused  with this was actually the reason why he started tutoring her (which led to the creation of the Khan Academy).
title: Unit conversion

children.title: Converting pounds to ounces
children.description: We can't tell you how many times in your life you will stare at a recipe and then need to use this skill. Trust us. Let's convert pounds to ounces!

children.title: Unit conversion: gallons to quarts, pints, and cups
children.description: What's the difference between gallons, quarts, pints, and cups? Soooo many people go their entire lives without knowing how to convert one unit of measure to another. Take note.

children.title: Converting yards into inches
children.description: Converting units of measure is a skill you'll encounter many times over in everyday life. In this example, we'll look at yards, feet, and inches.

children.title: Unit conversion: arithmetic calculations on units of volume
children.description: Sometimes we have different units of measure and are asked to add them up. The answer can't be stated in ALL units so we have to pick one unit of measure. In this example, you'll practice that scenario with us.

children.title: Unit measurement word problem: weight
children.description: We're moving between units of weight in this word problem. Ever get in an elevator with a bunch people and wonder to yourself, "How many people can this elevator safely hold?" Yeah, us too. You can solve that problem now.

children.title: Unit measurement word problem: converting units
children.description: Pints or gallons? Gallons or quarts? Confused? You won't be for long. This unit measurement word problem gets us thinking about moving between these units of volume.

children.title: Unit conversion word problem: roadtrip
children.description: The challenge in a word problem sometimes is knowing which numbers to choose when creating a simple equation. In this unit conversion word problem we'll answer the common question: "How much will a road trip cost me in gas?"

children.title: Multi-step unit conversion word problem
children.description: The fate of a squirrel is in your hands as it tries to run across the road before a car reaches it. Use what you know about unit conversion to help solve this word problem.

children.title: Unit measurement word problem: running laps
children.description: Remember that it's always easier to convert everything to like units before tackling a unit conversion word problem. That way your comparing apples to apples. Go for it...we'll explain as we work through it!

children.title: Unit conversion word problem: drug dosage
children.description: Future doctors and nurses out there, take note. This unit conversion word problem deals with converting drug dosage units, something that is commonly done in hospitals. Give it a try with us.

children.title: Unit conversion word problem: yards to inches
children.description: In this example, we need to convert from yards to inches. We'll do it a couple of ways.
Translating speed units
children.title: Speed translation

description:
You might be surprised to realize that only two countries in the world use feet, miles, or yards or a bunch of other "English System" conventions  (the irony being that the English don't even use the "English System" any more).   Everyone else, including the English, now use the metric system which is actually much more logical.

Learn about kilo and milli and centi and become a metric unit megastar!
title: Metric system unit conversion

children.description: Metric unit conversion

children.description: Converting within the metric system
children.title: Converting within the metric system

children.title: Conversion between metric units

description: There are three major conventions for measuring temperature in the world, Fahrenheit, Celsius and Kelvin.  If converting between the three gives you cold feet, then this tutorial might warm them up.
title: Fahrenheit and Celsius conversion

children.description: Converting Fahrenheit to Celsius
children.title: Converting Fahrenheit to Celsius
Comparing Celsius and Fahrenheit temperature scales
children.description: Comparing Celsius and Fahrenheit temperature scales

description: This tutorial is less about statistics and more about interpreting data--whether it is presented as a table, pictograph, bar graph or line graph.  Good for someone new to these ideas.  For a student in high school or college looking to learn statistics, it might make sense to skip (although it might not hurt either).
title: Reading and interpreting data

children.description: Stem-and-leaf Plots
children.title: Stem-and-leaf plots
Reading pictographs
children.description: Common sense tells you that a pictograph must be some kind of....picture. Yes! A pictograph is basically a way to represent data with pictures that relate to the data. Let's look at this word problem that asks to interpret a pictograph.
Reading Bar Graphs
children.title: Reading bar graphs

children.description: Histograms
children.title: Histograms
Reading bar charts: basic example
children.description: Let's start with this bar chart that brings back the days of Harry Potter! Putting our toes in the water on this one...

children.title: Creating a bar chart
children.description: We're going to create a bar chart together using using data from a survey.

children.title: Reading bar charts: comparing two sets of data
children.description: A bar chart is especially useful with comparing two sets of data. The difference in the bars give us a quick snapshot that allows us to draw some conclusions.

children.title: Reading bar charts: putting it together with central tendency
children.description: Let's combine some learning! Here we looking at bar charts and using the information to determine the measures of central tendency.

children.title: Reading line graphs
children.description: A line graph is another way to visually represent data, especially data that changes over time. They are extremely useful Let's take a look at this example.

children.title: Reading pie graphs (circle graphs)
children.description: Reading Pie Graphs (Circle Graphs)
Misleading Line Graphs

description: The world seldom gives you two numbers and tells you which operation to perform.  More likely, you'll be presented with a bunch of information and you (yes, YOU) need to make sense of them.  This tutorial gives you practice doing exactly that.  When watching videos, pause and attempt it before Sal.  Then work on as many problems as you want in the exercise at the end of the tutorial.
title: Multi-step word problems

children.title: Multi-step word problem with decimals and subtraction
children.description: First visualize this word problem then use subtraction and multiplication of decimals and fractions to get at the answer.

children.title: Multi-step word problem with fractions and units of time
children.description: Remember units of measurement? Convert minutes into hours and put your knowledge of fractions to work in this word problem.

children.title: Multi-step word problem with addition, subtraction, and multiplication
children.description: Budgeting money is one of the most valuable math skills you'll learn. Practice with us as we figure out how much money is left after a cab fare.

description:
Equality is usually a good thing, but the world is not a perfect place.  No matter how hard we try, we can't help but compare one thing to another and realize how unequal they may be.

This tutorial gives you the tools to do these comparisons in the mathematical world (which we call inequalities).  You'll become familiar with the "greater than" and "less than symbols" and learn to use them.
title: Inequalties : Greater than and less than basics

children.title: Greater than and less than symbols
Inequalities:  plotting on a number line
children.description: We've been taking a lot of equalities. What about when the relationships between numbers need to be expressed as inequalities? For example, less/greater than and/or equal to? How can we represent that idea on a number line?

children.title: Inequality word problems
children.description: We're writing inequalities by using information from the word problems. Woohoo!

children.title: Inequality word problem: one variable
children.description: This time we're creating a variable to represent  a number, and then writing an inequality. We're building on our knowledge.

children.title: Using inequalities to describe real-world contexts
A simple inequality: plotting on a number line
children.description: We're plotting a simple inequality on a number line in this example.
Write equations of inequalities graphed on number lines. Identify number line graphs of inequalities.
children.title: Inequalities on a number line

description: You've probably been learning how to do arithmetic for some time and feel pretty good about it.  This tutorial will make you feel even better once by showing you a bunch of examples of where it can be applied (using multiple skills at a time).  Get through the exercises here and you really are an arithmetic rock star!
title: Cross topic arithmetic

children.title: Rational number word problem with fractions
children.description: Word problems force us to put concepts to work using real-world applications. In this example, determine the volume of frozen water and express the answer as a fraction.

children.title: Rational number word problem with ratios
children.description: In this word problem, we'll compare the weight of two objects using a ratio of integers. We'll practice simplifying a fraction, too.

children.title: Rational number word problem with proportions
children.description: Use your knowledge of proportions and fractions to determine shareholders profit in this word problem.

children.title: Rational number word problem with decimals
children.description: Your checking account is overdrawn. Not good. Use your knowledge of decimals and adding negative and positive numbers to bring your account back into the black.

description: Let's explore how numbers can grow in different ways and use what we learn to figure out where they can go.  We think you'll find this tutorial on number patterns more fun that you do :)
title: Number patterns

children.title: Using factors and multiples to figure out days of the week
children.description: Can you help us think of a mathematical way to determine what day of the week a certain number day falls on? You may say no....but wait! Watch this.

children.title: Math patterns example 1
children.description: Part of our exploration of math is learning to identify patterns among numbers. Can you see the pattern in this example?

children.title: Math patterns example 2
children.description: We continue to strengthen our skill in identifying patterns. This time we'll use a table to track the pattern.

children.title: Number patterns: Seeing relationships
children.description: Laying the foundation for algebraic thinking by learning to recocognize the relationships between paterns and graphing out those relationships.

children.title: Number patterns: interpreting relationships
children.description: Examining the points on a number line and interpreting the patterns to discover the relationships.

children.title: Number patterns:: interpreting and graphing relationships
children.description: We're building in complexity as we interpret and graph the relationships between patterns in the given ordered pairs. Don't stress. We're here to help!

children.title: Visualizing and interpreting relationships between patterns

description: Let's construct and interpret expressions from word problems.  We can also think about what the effects of parentheses are.
title: Constructing numeric expressions

children.title: Constructing numerical expressions
children.description: This word problem can be solved by constructing a numerical expression. Can you help?  We bet you can!

children.title: Evaluating expressions with and without parentheses
children.description: So maybe parentheses don't seem like a big deal? Check out this problem and the difference in the answer when you work it without the parentheses. Wow.
Practice creating expressions with parentheses from real-world contexts.
children.title: Creating expressions with parentheses

description: Most of us are use to using the digits 0-9 to represent numbers in the base-10 (decimal)number system.  In this tutorial, we'll see that is just one of many (really infinite) number systems.  In particular, we will focus on the binary (base-2) and hexadecimal (base-16) systems.
title: Binary and hexadecimal number systems

children.title: Introduction to number systems and binary
children.description: Thinking about number systems.  Comparing and explain decimal (base 10) and binary (base 2) number systems.

children.description: Hexadecimal number system (base 16)

description:
Addition was nice.  Multiplication was cooler.  In the mood for a new operation that grows numbers even faster?  Ever felt like expressing repeated multiplication with less writing?  Ever wanted to describe how most things in the universe grow and shrink?  Well, exponents are your answer!

This tutorial covers everything from basic exponents to negative and fractional ones.  It assumes you remember your multiplication, negative numbers and fractions.
title: The world of exponents

children.title: Exponentiation warmup
children.description: introduction to exponents and exponential growth

children.title: Introduction to exponents
children.description: Taking an exponent is basically the act of repeated multiplication. You know how to multiply, right? If so, understanding exponents is completely within your grasp!

children.title: Raising a number to the 0 and 1st power
children.description: The progression of powers from zero to any non-zero number follows a pattern and can be logically explained. After watching this, it will make sense why any non-zero number to the zero power equals one.

children.title: Powers of 1 and 0
children.description: Let's see what happens with bases to the zero power, plus we'll reinforce the patterns of applying exponents to postive and negative bases.

children.title: Powers of fractions
children.description: Just like whole numbers with exponents, fractions are repeatedly multiplied. If you know how to multiply factions, you're over half way there.

children.title: Powers of zero
children.description: We know that any non-zero number to the zero power equals one. We also know that zero to any non-zero exponent equals one. What happens when you have zero to the zero power?

children.title: Positive exponents with positive and negative bases

children.description: Integers raised to positive integers. Non-zero integers raised to the zero power. 0, -1, and 1 raised to very large positive integers.
children.title: Positive and zero exponents with positive and negative bases

description:
A strong contender for coolest symbol in mathematics is the radical.  What is it?  How does it relate to exponents?  How is the square root different than the cube root?  How can I simplify, multiply and add these things?  

This tutorial assumes you know the basics of exponents and exponent properties and takes you through the radical world for radicals (and gives you some good practice along the way)!
title: The square root

children.description: Understanding Square Roots

children.description: Using exponent rules to simplify radicals or square roots

children.description: Express radicals in simplest form.
children.title: Simplifying square roots

children.description: Multiply expressions containing radicals.

children.description: More Simplifying Radical Expressions

children.description: Add and subtract expressions containing radicals.

description: If you're familiar with the idea of a square root, we're about to take things one step (dimension?) further with the cube root.  This generally refers to finding a number that ,when cubed, is equal to the number that you're trying to find the cube root of!

description:
Tired of hairy exponent expressions?  Feel compelled to clean them up?  Well, this tutorial might just give you the tools you need.

If you know a bit about exponents, you'll learn a ton more in this tutorial as you learn about the rules for simplifying exponents.
title: Exponent properties

children.description: Introduction to exponent rules
children.title: Exponent rules part 1

children.description: 2 more exponent rules with an introduction to composite problems

children.description: Exponent Properties Involving Quotients
children.title: Exponent properties involving quotients

description:
It's normally a bad idea to hang around with negative people or do negative things, but we think it's OK to associate with negative exponents.  And fractional exponents are even more fun.

This idea will open up entirely new vistas to your mathematical life.
title: Negative and fractional exponents

children.description: Intuition on why a^-b = 1/(a^b) (and why a^0 =1)

Zero, negative, and fractional exponents
children.description: Zero, Negative, and Fractional Exponents
Fractional and integer bases raised to positive and negative integer exponents.
children.title: Positive and negative exponents

description:
Scientists and engineers often have to deal with super huge (like 6,000,000,000,000,000,000,000) and super small numbers (like 0.0000000000532) .  How can they do this without tiring their hands out?  How can they look at a number and understand how large or small it is without counting the digits?  The answer is to use scientific notation.

If you come to this tutorial with a basic understanding of positive and negative exponents, it should leave you with a new appreciation for representing really huge and really small numbers!
title: Scientific notation

children.title: Introduction to scientific notation
children.description: Introduction to scientific notation.  An in-depth discussion about why and how scientific notation is used.
Scientific Notation
children.title: Scientific notation

children.description: Move a decimal point to express a number in scientific notation.

children.description: More scientific notation examples

children.description: Scientific Notation I
children.title: Scientific notation I

children.description: Scientific Notation 2

children.description: Express a number in scientific notation.
children.title: Scientific notation

description: When people want to think about the general size of things but not worry about the exact number, they tend to think in terms of "orders of magnitude".  This allows us to analyze and make comparisons between numbers very quickly, which allows us to make decisions about them quickly as well.
title: Orders of magnitude

children.title: Exponents and powers of zero patterns
children.description: Now that we understand how to interpret an exponent and how the patterns in zeros are related to the exponent, we can solve more complicated problems!

description: You already understand what scientific notation is.  Now you'll actually use it to compute values and solve real-world problems.
title: Computing with scientific notation

children.description: u11_l1_t4_we_int Multiplying in Scientific Notation
children.title: Multiplying in scientific notation
Multiplying in scientific notation example
children.description: Multiplying in scientific notation example
Example showing how to divide two numbers expressed in scientific notation

children.description: Express a product or quotient in scientific notation.
